There is a protein folding experiment named Rosetta which uses the spare “screen saver” computing power in computers owned by volunteers. If you’re interested, you can look it up on BOINC, the Berkeley Open Interface for Numeric Computing. The researchers at Berkeley developed a process for splitting up data from radio telescopes so that subscribers’ computers could be used to search for possible intelligence-related signals in the SETI (Search for Extra Terrestrial Intelligence) project.

A few years later, they developed a program to multitask this project, SETI@Home, with a variety of projects for other scientific disciplines.

An interested volunteer only has to download from the BOINC website the appropriate version of BOINC, and download from each research project (via the BOINC website) the program for each project one wishes to help. The downloading of new data sets and uploading of results happens automatically, but does not require exorbitant internet time; each data set does lots of computing before it needs to be returned to get more data, using the CPU time and other resources available when the user is not actively using the computer.
So it's machine learning, basically.

If you're wondering, simulated annealing could in fact be used for training neural nets instead of gradient descent, but it's more computationally costly, and finding the global minimum to the loss function (as opposed to a good local minimum) isn't desirable because it can result in overfitting the data and prevent the model from generalizing.

I understand that for the metaphor you kinda have to state that actual annealing only cools slowly but that's actually not true. I anneal for part of a hobby of mine. This hobby requires incredible accuracy and scientific scales that measure fractions of a gram and my margin for error is unbelievably small. When I anneal I actually immediately drop the metal into a water bath to rapidly cool it. This is because once heated the metal finds that lower (softer) state and I want to cool it before it has a chance to revert back to its higher (harder and more brittle) state. Again, I understand that for the purpose of this video you have to say annealing only cools slowly but for the curious viewers reading the comment section, I would like to state that not all annealing involves slowly cooling a metal. It just depends on what kind of metal and what result you are looking to get.

This has been around forever. We did simulated annealing in image processing back in the early 1990s. It was not always the best method. Simulated annealing is a numerical method; today we'd use Machine Learning much more to solve these kinds of questions.

We've heard of lots of problem-solvers, most of which don't pan out. "Studying nature" is not a solution - it's an approximation, and not a particularly good one. "Discovering the underlying equations" is the solution, but getting the intern you've hired because you're too cheap to hire an actual computer scientist to do that is a dead end. This is just that old "approximation" game; we heard exactly this with "probability" techniques, which don't work at all, unless you're lucky (I'm not kidding), and whatever works for one set of data (or many sets) may fail spectacularly on 'unexpected' (that is to say, real-world) data. Oh yeah, and "100s of papers" is not a recommendation at all. Have you read journal or proceeding papers? A bigger pile of sham 'results' and 'surveys' is not to be found... in nature.
It's a variation of the Monte-Carlo simulation.

Simulated annealing is not an algorithm. It is a metaheuristic, meaning, a type of heuristic, which in itself is a type of algorithm, not any one specific algorithm. Heuristics are algorithms that used statistics to get "good enough" answers. And simulated annealing is one way to do that. But it's a kind of algorithm, not an algorithm itself. The algorithms used in to find a protein structure may not be the same for the one used for finding the best box shape. Even when both are simulated annealing algorithms.

"if you want to work a piece of metal into a certain shape it's best if the atoms are all neatly arranged in a crystal structure"... dislocations (a type of defect that can move through a metal crystal) are the reason forging works at all, and the crystal structure shown is Hexagonal Cose Packing, notoriously brittle. That sounds an awful lot like training neural networks. You shuffle the weights around randomly and check what the error of the whole system is, and the lower the error is the less you shuffle it around between each check. At the end you should have something close to optimal if your architecture works for the problem.

Some quantum computers use a form of annealing too.They can go from a superposition of all states to settling on the lowest possible energy configuration which represents the answer.

While they are very powerful in this, they are limited to only solving this class of problem, and can't be used to run a variety of apps the way your phone can.

I love it when you do episodes on things I study in University! I do a lot of work with Markov-Chain Monte Carlo and use a technique similar to this called Parallel Tempering. It can do similar things, but has the advantage of having the result with error bars at the expense of computational time.

If you like that, check out the Stigler Diet https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stigler_diet He came up with the least cost diet for a minimum number of foods that satisfies basic nutrition.

We did not have the math to describe the problem when he was working in the 1940s, so he did it by trial and error. Eventually, once linear programming was developed, they ran the problem again and Stiglers solution was within a dollar a year of the algorithmic solution.

- welfare

Why is this brought up now? I remember this from my electronics studies during the mid nineties, when these kind of optimization algorithms were all the rage (and actively used) for finding optimal settings for electronic controllers, neural networks and a number of other things. I remember it being called "machine learning" or "organic algorithms" back then. Essentially finding optimal solutions by starting with large deviations in variables, and (automatically) dialing in progressively smaller optimizing variations, until you got within an acceptably stable (or tracking) solution. Did it really take more than 25 years to figure out that this can be used for other things too?
Do more of these types of shows.

Simulated annealing is a probabilistic method which targets to achieve global optimal solution of any given problem...sure it works in several areas but genetic algorithms (like NSGA -II)offer better results in specific cases like in robotics, data mining, network simulation and many more.

Oh damn, I actually theorized an algorithm like this in HS! I came up with a description for genetic algorithms that helped me understand them better by describing the possible states of the machine as a 3D surface where the algorithm would search for the lowest possible point by measuring the incline of its current point. I didn’t like that explanation because it was very easy for the system to get stuck at a local minimum instead of the true minimum, so I devised a method where the system would first start out making random changes and then gradually start paying more attention to the slope of the surface over time. Sounds like that’s exactly what this is! I never did anything with my theory and I work in avionics now...

In order to this work we need extremely well data gathering which in most cases is very hard to impossible. For example, as soon as you get someone with a stopwatch, and clipboard behind an employee to track their time to do something, he/she immediate get suspicious and start to working faster than they normally would. When the point is to get the normal average time. Of course you can hide the data collector behind a camera or use sophisticated measure methods, like counting every product made with a scanner. If done wright your optimization will work. But mapping all the factors is a daunting task, make sure that you can adjust those parameters on the fly is impossible. Like, how does you factor in a pandemic impacts on your supply chain? So with time the model gets outdated, and it will generate inconsistent results. Eventually people will start to use spreadsheets that they understand as the model annealing it again.

Sounds like a Genetic Algorithm. They mutate and cross over in similar ways to escape local maxima and find the global maxima. They also start randomly and randomly mutate with selections of new genes potenetially including those with lower fitness score that helps to escape some local maximum. I wonder if you could apply simulated annealing to optimize for neural networks.
This process is equivalent to finding a new local maxima on an n-dimensional fitness landscape. It can be optimized with pathing algorithms, traveling salesman, etc.

In Biology, "metabolic engineering" is a discipline where algorithms are used to solve optimization problems. For example, it is desirable to genetically engineer microbes so that they can be more efficiently used in different industry sectors. In principle, microbes are naturally adapted so a specific environment and scientist try to modify them (using algorithms HOW they should modify them) in order to produce antiniotics, amino acids or vitamins.
